results.title: Reminding Canadians of Egg Safety this Easter
results.description: Shop carefully: Choose refrigerated <mark>eggs</mark> with clean shells that aren’t cracked. Pick up <mark>eggs</mark> and other cold foods at the end of your shopping trip so they stay cold.  … Keep <mark>eggs</mark> cold: Refrigerate <mark>eggs</mark> within two hours of purchase and place them in the coldest part of the refrigerator in their original carton; don’t keep <mark>eggs</mark> in the refrigerator door.

results.title: Reminding Canadians of Egg Safety This Easter
results.description:
You can reduce your risk of contracting foodborne illness from <mark>eggs</mark> by following a few simple tips.

  … Hard-cooked <mark>eggs</mark>, in shell or peeled, and pickled <mark>eggs</mark> can be stored in the refrigerator for up to one week.

results.title: Archived – The Government of Canada Reminds Canadians of Egg Safety
results.description:
Hard boiled <mark>eggs</mark> and pickled <mark>eggs</mark> can be stored in the refrigerator for up to one week. If you include <mark>eggs</mark> in your lunch, make sure to include an icepack to keep the <mark>eggs</mark> cold.

  … Easter <mark>eggs</mark>: Decorating hard-boiled <mark>eggs</mark> at Easter is a popular activity. Decorated <mark>eggs</mark> that have been left out on display are not safe to eat.

results.title: Archived – Health Canada Reminds Canadians of Egg Safety
results.description:
It is also possible to contaminate <mark>eggs</mark> with bacteria from other foods. You can avoid contracting foodborne illness from <mark>eggs</mark> by following a few food safety tips.

  … Easter <mark>eggs</mark>: Decorating hard-boiled <mark>eggs</mark> at Easter is a popular activity. Decorated <mark>eggs</mark> that have been left out on display are not safe to eat.

results.title: Reminding Canadians of Egg Safety this Easter
results.description:
Keep <mark>eggs</mark> cold: Store <mark>eggs</mark> in the original carton in the body of the refrigerator instead of in the refrigerator door.
 
   … If you hard-boil <mark>eggs</mark>:

 
  Cook <mark>eggs</mark> thoroughly in boiling water.
 
  Cool <mark>eggs</mark> completely by immersing in cold tap water, and make sure they are kept cold before and after they are dyed.

results.title: Information Update - Reminding Canadians of Egg Safety this Easter
results.description: Farm fresh <mark>eggs</mark>: Do not wash farm fresh <mark>eggs</mark> until you are ready to use them. Washing an egg can remove the protective "bloom" that prevents bacteria from entering <mark>eggs</mark> and keeps them fresh.  … Keep <mark>eggs</mark> cold: <mark>Eggs</mark> stored at room temperature spoil more quickly than refrigerated ones. Keep store-bought <mark>eggs</mark> in the original carton in the body of the refrigerator.
